Was never interested in playing Fruit Machines in my life. This game is amazing, however.  

I felt that I was becoming less and less interested in games because it was like I'd just done it all before. Never going to get that feeling of playing Oblivion for the first time again; GTA Story Mode won't have the same effect it used to have on us. These are experiences we've all had countless times, and furthermore, they have been endlessly copied and re-released, often on a yearly basis. Everyone is doing what is safe and not creative. It becomes incredibly stagnant.

Then come along indie games. Originally stuff like Isaac, Nuclear Throne, Darkest Dungeon, etc. Then Hades happens, and roguelite/indie games get some mainstream spotlight. Everyone is trying to make a game like Hades, and even this space started to stagnate for a moment there.

Enter 2025, the year that broke the mold (again). I've seen so many original ideas this year, maybe something that at a glance you think "WTF even is that?" but if you play it, it just makes sense. It takes all of the things that feel great about playing a roguelite but offers a completely new way of delivering it; it's like scooters to spaceships with the variety, too.

Sorry, this is less a review of this game specifically and more of a general praise to the indie/roguelite scene for the games on my radar recently, Clover Pit being a front runner for GOTY, personally.

Just play it; if I start to describe the game, I'll just spoil some of it. Best you just experience it for yourself.

A sinister roguelite where you have to make enough cash to survive every round via gambling on a slot machine. Randomized items and power-ups ensure that the experience is varied whenever you decide to allow yourself to be trapped inside a small room to just eventually get killed anyway. Great morbid atmosphere further amplified by the low tech graphics with a dose of dark humor. CloverPit further proves that in gaming, replayability is king and you never have to spend a lot of money to play the best of games.

Developed by Panik Arcade and published by Future Friends Games, Clover Pit is a rogue-lite slot machine simulator released at the end of September 2025. 

Deceitfully simple, addictingly complex, this game is easy to start, but to learn combinations and mechanics hidden in plain sight takes some time and experimentation.  

The basic gameplay loop consists of gambling coins in the slot machine to deposit ever increasing amounts in the ATM. Also present in the small dark room with you is a table with trinkets that warp and twist mechanics, such as luck, payout, and even number of spins available, bought with tickets awarded every turn. 

Secrets and items can be unlocked by repeated playing sessions, which in turn push the basic mechanics of the game. 

Although some parts of the game seem purposefully unfair, the challenge of winning each round is incredibly appealing, and as a huge plus the rogue-lite elements, that provide the game a considerably huge replay value. As of the time of writing, there has been a DLC teased, possibly adding more secrets and mechanics to an already great game. For these reasons, I recommend this game. 

If you enjoyed this review, I would like to invite you to visit [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44722081/] [u]Backlog log[/u] [/url] my curator page for more recommendations and reviews.

Good and fun game. I really enjoy the horror elements and the retro look to the game overall.

There isn't much to say about this game's gameplay. You run a slot machine over and over again to pay off mysterious and increasing debts with the twist of having the ability to rig the slot machine in your favour (or not if you so choose :P). You have three goes at the slot machine per "deadline" to make up the money required to progress, otherwise...

This is an incredibly addicting game to play, I have managed to (as of now) 100% the game. The gameplay loop is very repetitive but it's still fun regardless trying out different setups and charms, seeing how many different ways you can succeed (or fail). Finding ways to deal with the charms you've been dealt to succeed is very fun and especially rewarding if you manage to pull it off. I'd always be trying to find ways to break the slot machines in new ways to see how much money I could accumulate throughout the run.

The graphics in this game are very reminiscent of Buckshot Roulette and I love it. It fits the vibe of the game and its gameplay perfectly in my opinion.

You start out with a base set of charms and more can be unlocked by just simply playing the game. Some charms require you to play in a different way than you may be comfortable to unlock them. However doing so adds a bit of variety to the gameplay loop which I'm always appreciative of and which is especially needed in gameplay as simple as this. 

Unlike most roguelike games, this one focuses a little more heavily on luck over similar (and also excellent) games like Balatro. The first two or three deadlines are effectively the make or break of your run, if you get a good initial charm setup, you're almost certain to win but if not you'll have to restart and hope for a better shop. While luck always tends to play some role in this genre, I feel like it can be a bit too heavy at times, especially with the new implemented hard mode (which I'll get to later). Along with this, while the first two deadlines are (sometimes) quite hard to pass, once you do it's a free run to the finish line. It would be nice for a little more challenge throughout the run since once you get the formula down for the game you can pretty much guarantee a win every time.

One of the major problems I've had with this game lies in the memory cards. These are effectively modifications to the run that you can make to change how you play. I really enjoy playing the memory cards. However, what I don't enjoy is that they're consumable. You effectively need to obtain them during runs and playing runs with them eats into their supply. This is quite frustrating when I was doing for the last achievement I needed in the game "Lord of the Pit" which in order to beat you need to complete a memory card in "hard mode" which doubles the deadline completion requirement. this is very heavily luck based.

When I was playing, I could only pass the first deadline every 1 in 3 times and the second deadline every 1 in 5 which I wouldn't be too bothered about if it didn't eat into my limited supply of memory cards. I feel like memory cards should be obtained by a different method than what currently exists in game and they should not be consumable as they are now.

One last gripe I have with this game is that while I love the gameplay in this game but some of the choices made by the devs are a little questionable in my opinion. Most of the fun for some players in rougelikes and rougelites comes from the ability to break the game in exciting ways, infinite scaling, broken synergies, etc... While the devs have explicitly said that they haven't removed the ability to obtain "endless runs" they nerfed a lot of the charms in game and bumped up deadline requirements in the late game to make it harder to do so. I believe this was a wrong choice. The devs should be encouraging new ways to create endless runs to break the game by buffing some of the less helpful charms giving new and exciting ways to break the slot machine. 

A new update is around the corner, I'm excited to see what's in store with the newly announced DLC and I'll be sure to play it though :D

Overall, despite a few of my gripes, I strongly recommend this game, it's incredibly fun to play and I really enjoyed my time playing it to achieve 100%. I'll be keeping an eye out for the future of this game and what else the developers have in store for us, for now though... Let's go Gambling!!

CloverPit certainly nails being a slot machine nightmare, and to some extent it works as a satisfying rogue-lite as well.

The PSX-style graphics, atmosphere, and sound design are excellent, and they do a good job of drawing you in. There is some very light narrative and atmospheric storytelling, but I honestly hoped for something more developed.

The novelty of the gameplay loop and rogue-lite progression is exciting at first. It‚Äôs visually satisfying too, with all elements being physical objects in the game world. Getting a good spin on the slot machine, inspecting your trinkets, and watching the numbers go up feels tactile and fun.

But as you progress and figure out the optimal strategies for beating pure RNG, the cracks start to show. CloverPit lacks agency, and as the novelty fades, it lacks surprises.
After seeing its ending at around 15 hours, I can‚Äôt help but feel there could have been more.

I still had a good time with CloverPit, until I didn‚Äôt. And in that sense, it was a worthwhile experience.
I really don‚Äôt like this game‚Äôs early game RNG at all. If you‚Äôre not lucky, there‚Äôs basically no way to meet the deadline in the beginning it‚Äôs way too dependent on pure RNG

The game is great but i have 2 big issues with it which puts it behind Nubby and Balatro for me.

2 Main issues:

Memory Packs: Its straight stupid to gate different playthroughs behind charges. Every "run modifier" can very easily run out if you don't win the run, gating them off and forcing you to do a boring run just for a chance at another try. The whole point of the memory packs for other games like balatro is extra content with new rules for people who've gotten bored of the base game. So making those same people have to do pointless normal runs just to re-unlock them is cheap. Once I own those cards I should be able to do that kind of run whenever I want. I've completed the milestone and now you're making me do chores to re-visit the endgame. Even if it can later be unlocked to be permanent, i see no logical reason to gate them at all.

Luck: Luck is defined very wierdly in this game, and since its the core stat of the game I think needs changing. Luck doesn't synergise well with many builds based on specific symbols. at around 5 luck it will give a more likely chance for the same symbol to show up, based on your odds of each symbol. This is perfect as is. If you accidentally gain more than that much luck, it starts to become a downgrade as it will do the same but for higher value symbols like 7's and diamonds, no matter their odds of actually appearing. Having this be a mixture between a really good proc and really bad proc for many builds leads to an unfun gamble of stats, where your build can be too good and give you too much luck making your jackpot hit for 500 because it was diamonds, and not 3 million because it was lemons (most common). I understand why its like this, as I guess its the most realistic way of doing a luck stat but if it makes most builds encounter this issue just change it.

Items: i think they gave a good variety and there's definately enough in the game to make games unique, but they all revolve around 3-5 playstyles which is a shame, the main 2 being "symbol proc" and "luck stacking".

EDIT 2: The devs have made a post about how they're listening to feedback and such, so there's hope yet, but until we see the actual changes, it's hard to say whether it's 'safe' to buy the game, so to speak. It'll depend on what we actually see. Especially since they announced a DLC only a few days later, which just reads badly even when giving the complete benefit of the doubt and saying this was something already planned and they made the decision not to delay the announcement despite what's been going on surrounding the 1.2 update. The fact that there's a DLC being announced before the game has even been out for two months doesn't bode well to begin with, too, so a lot of players are assuming the worst.

To be COMPLETELY fair, it's not clear whether the DLC is paid or not as of yet, as far as I've seen. If it [i]is[/i] free, though, it probably would've been wisest to say that upfront, or better yet, not make it a 'dlc' at all and instead a free update. It does seem like a lot of players have forgotten that devs (as a whole, not just in the case of CloverPit) aren't really obligated to provide ANY new content for free. It's become common practice, it seems, but when it comes to a game that's released complete, there's no good reason to demand devs add more things. If a game wants to sell DLC, that's perfectly fine. But there's definitely a consideration to be made for timing, as well as the general attitude towards DLC these days. It's just another thing that's not really helping the playerbase's agitation, unfortunately.

In any case, my hope is that the devs truly have learned something in all of this and are able to sift through the vitriol and such to understand what's gone wrong, here. For all the game's flaws, it's a fun time, and I'll be happy to recommend it if things improve, but until I actually see it, I just can't recommend the game. Unfortunately, the gaming sphere has seen far, far too many broken promises to really take any dev at their word.

[ Prev Reviews ] (Going to cut down and summarize my previous posts bc with the edits, it's gotten too long to be practical)
CloverPit is probably still worth the money, especially on sale, but the 1.2 update was an utter fiasco that has left a large portion of the playerbase varying levels of upset and angry with the devs. The changes made in the 1.2 update are generally hostile towards players, including item changes that are near universally nerfs with only a few very minor buffs and one item rework that I‚Äôve found makes the item unusable rather than better. The update also changed the parameters of an achievement by making hard mode required for it, which, due to the game‚Äôs very low skill ceiling and lacking opportunities for skill expression, makes getting said achievement an exercise in patience at best, and at worst, an utterly miserable grind that‚Äôs far more luck-based than before, as well as functionally tossing out significant chunks of progress myself and others made towards said achievement prior to 1.2.
The 1.2 update has only been received more poorly as word has spread about why some of the changes were implemented, as well as one particular Instagram post that comes across very, [i]very[/i] poorly, found here: https://www.instagram.com/reel/DRAPaLakwpW 
(In case it gets deleted in the future or is inaccessible for some other reason, it‚Äôs a short video with the captions of ‚Äúhow it feels knowing i just made my game twice as hard for y‚Äôall [smiling face with hearts emoji, ribbon emoji, twinkle emoji]‚Äù and ‚Äúdouble deadline amounts good luck teehee [smiling face with hearts emoji x4]‚Äù with pictures of smiling/smug cats flipping over gameplay footage.
Even when giving as much benefit of the doubt as I can, that this is a dev seeing the backlash and believing it‚Äôs simply people who are upset the game isn‚Äôt ‚Äú‚Äù‚Äùeasy‚Äù‚Äù‚Äù anymore or thinking it‚Äôs just a very few noisy people and the majority are content with the update, this is an extremely immature thing to put up. It‚Äôs no surprise, however, that most of those who saw it took it for what it most clearly appears to be, antagonism towards the players who are upset with an update that makes the game less fun to play. And even giving said benefit of the doubt, this is still functionally telling players to just ‚Äògit gud‚Äô at a game that, as I said before, has an extremely low skill ceiling and simply doesn‚Äôt have much to actually improve upon in terms of player skill.

Early on, while getting unlocks and getting memory cards, this game is actually pretty good. It was a fun and simple rougelite that was hard, and took a bit to get the train rolling to understand and get better at this game. And that's what makes some of the best rougelites out there, simple to play but difficult to master, with lots of fun unlocks helping greatly.

But these devs want to cater to about 5 or 6 youtubers than are known for breaking games and making infinite money. As such, they are nerfing every other item to the ground. For a single player game, this is absurd, but normally these patches didn't dramatically affect games, you could still master this. This only affected maybe 5% of people playing to the extremes.

Until their recent 1.2 patch. The only challenge left for me was memory cards, which each one had a unique and fresh experience making players rethink entire strategies. Now, with the change to rainbow cards, say goodbye to that achievement. Expect to reset a run 10+ times just to get lucky enough for the FIRST deadline. Thank you Panik Arcade for catering to a couple Youtube slop videos, which by the way is what made your game popular in the first place. As a congratulations for selling 1 MILLION copies, ruin the experience for everyone else.

I genuinely loved CloverPit up until the 1.2 update. I‚Äôve put a good amount of time into the game and was steadily working toward 100% completion. I was totally happy to keep grinding, until this patch essentially punished anyone who hadn‚Äôt already finished the hardest achievements.

The biggest issue is the new requirement for upgrading memory cards to holographic. Previously, you unlocked holographic versions by winning with that card three times. Now you must beat that card in the newly-added Hard Mode, where your debt is doubled. This change sounds fine in theory, but in practice it makes several memory cards borderline impossible to clear. Some cards already alter the game so heavily that just winning once is difficult, doubling the debt on those cards turns them into instant ‚Äúthrowaways.‚Äù And unfortunately, you need every card holographic to unlock a certain achievment.

Players who already earned the achievement before 1.2? They‚Äôre done. Players like me, who were one card away? We‚Äôre now facing challenges that are mathematically close to unwinnable. The last card I needed was Delusions of Granduer, which doubles your debt. I was one win away from turning it holographic. Now, to make it holographic, I have to beat that card with the debt doubled again. You can‚Äôt even get out of the first round on Hard Mode with some of these setups.

On top of that, the charm ‚Äúrebalancing‚Äù is almost entirely a series of nerfs. The patch describes these changes as making things ‚Äúfairer,‚Äù but the reality is that these nerfs further cripple certain strategies. Combined with the new Hard Mode requirement, the update effectively raises the difficulty floor while removing many of the tools players used to manage that difficulty.

This patch didn‚Äôt just make the game harder, it retroactively made achievements harder. That means players who didn‚Äôt get lucky before the update are now permanently behind. Instead of rewarding long-term play, this update undercuts it.

Dev encourages players to find synergies between items to tip the scales of luck in their favor. When streamers find synergies that let them bend the game over their knee, (which is really fun and what they were told to do,) the dev proceeds to nerf every powerful item without stating any other reason than over powered sorry as to why. This game went from feeling like a difficult but fun gambling game to something that felt like you were actively being crippled in every run if you were able to get past deadline one.

A single player roguelike shouldn't be getting nerf bats swung at popular strategies like it's in an online multiplayer game. If you want build diversity, buff the other lucky charms to make them more viable, not nerf into non-usability the lucky charms you view as "broken." The fun of rogue-likes like this for a lot of people is to break the score cap as much as possible and see how ridiculous of an endless run you can get, and this most recent patch has gutted the games ability to provide that. I won't be playing this game again unless I see indications that the ideology behind these nerfs has been given up, and the game is fun again. Not to mention how annoying it is to get specific memory cards and win with them, but now to foil them for the achievement, you have to beat the new hard mode with those memory cards, no option for the previous option of winning 3 runs with those memory cards.

TL;DR - New patch = no fun, please reconsider your ideas behind why nerfing those charms seemed like the right path forward for this game.

I got instantly hooked on this game when a friend introduced it to me, to the point it's the first game I ever tried to 100% purely out of enjoyment. However, the recent update has lead to nothing but disappointment.

CloverPot's new item description is confusing. There are also typos in the description of some items. A very sloppy update from my perspective. The recent nerfs took out a lot of things without enough buffs or changes to supplement for what was lost. Endless run strats may feel cheap, but those were only viable because building with other items that are very underwhelming is not enjoyable either. Besides, these endless runs are optional -- if the player finds it cheap or not fun to play, they don't HAVE to try these strategies.

Also ever since 1.2 dropped, I have noticed the CPU usage of CloverPit randomly jumps between 3% - 20% on my device. After having the game open for a while, the game is completely laggy and I go from 120 frames per second to 30 frames per chance.

Instead of nerfing/buffing items, perhaps consider adding Quality of Life changes to the game. There are several things that I feel require more attention than knocking out endless run strats which aren't even required to beat the game. I propose the following QoL:
- hotswapping items in drawers,
- automatic unpacking of memory cards,
- auto-decline deals,
- accessibility settings to reduce the amount of flashy animations in the game (the game becomes an eyesore at one point just because it blinds you...)
- additional speed settings or animation skip settings.

Again, truly enjoy the game prior to the update. It's just sadly unplayable for me; not even because of the nerfs, but because of optimization issues and lag. Needing to restart my game every few other run due to the FPS drop is exhausting.

This game needs a "toggler" feature like megabonk. There's waaay more trash items here. It was fun at the start, actually winning 3 straight games back to back (unlocking the key). But after you unlock enough items, the item pool gets diluted with garbage effects and it starts to feel bad. 

Too many runs die with no fault of your own. At least balatro feels it's possible to beat all seeds to be beatable until purple stakes and up. It's amazing to think about how balanced balatro's joker cards with the sheer amount of cards there and it doesn't need to have a toggler to do it.

After spending over 100 hours with Cloverpit, I really wanted to like it. The concept, visuals, and overall theme are fantastic. But once you dig into the gameplay, the cracks start to show and the recent update only made things worse.

Charm variety is extremely limited. Out of 125 charms, maybe a couple dozen were ever worth using before the update. Now, after a wave of over-nerfs, only a handful feel viable at all. Runs already tended to play out the same way before. Now they‚Äôre even more samey. You‚Äôll almost always end up going clovers or bells because they‚Äôre far and away the strongest options. Lemons and cherries can work, but anything built around diamonds, treasures, or sevens is basically doomed from the start. Their associated charms just don‚Äôt scale or synergize well enough to compete.

The new ‚Äúhard mode‚Äù sounded promising, but it completely misses the mark. Doubling the coin requirements across all deadlines doesn‚Äôt make the game more challenging in a fun or strategic way. It just makes the early game miserable and heavily luck-dependent. What used to be about making smart early choices to build momentum is now just praying your first shop doesn‚Äôt screw you.

A smarter approach would‚Äôve been to scale difficulty gradually. For example, keeping the first deadline the same, then ramping up by +10%, +20%, and so on rather than a flat 2x multiplier from the start. As it stands, ‚Äúhard mode‚Äù feels less like a skill test and more like ‚Äúluck mode.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a great foundation here, but the lack of charm variety, repetitive run structure, and misguided balance changes make Cloverpit tough to recommend in its current state.

Seriously, including Hard-Mode (Doubling Deadline cost), FORCING it on the memory Cards to get Rainbow, removing Endless Runs AND nerf an entire mechanic without buffing anything usefull to give playable alternatives. 

Seriously, the first Deadline was aways the critical one since it's the one deciding if the run even starts. And now, instead of just needing 45 coins, you need effing 150 coins . . . for the FIRST DEADLINE! With ONLY 2 CLOVERTICKETS! Especially if the Shop doesn't offer useful or purchasable charms, since they're expensive or VERY situational.
Sometimes devs sit down and think: He have this nice lil singleplayer game here that people enjoy. How about... not? And then nerf the shit out of it

GOLD GOLD GOLD

What it felt like a really innovative and exciting (to some degree) take on the rogue-lite genre turned out to be a completely limited gameplay wise game. 
The variety which is inherent to this type of games is gone after an hour or two of gameplay. After that, you left with only one slot machine inside this narrow room. 
If only there were some progression that unlocks new slots or at least new skins for the existing one. The interaction part of the slot itself is also insanely limited; you don't have any interactions outside of the spin lever and the button that increase some passive bonuses. There are plenty of ways to make it more engaging (just look at the real online slots) and fun to play.

the devs dont want you to have long runs and use the game mechanics as intended... ...so they nerfed the game with a recent patch... for some reason... in a single player game... 

all of the really good items suck now. was great before this patch, dont recommend now.

cant recommend until new update is either reverted or changed to address the criticisms

also, the 666 mechanic is not fun and could use some work. it feels like it triggers way more often than just 2% or whatever the base amount is. in my opinion how it works needs to be changed, if not how often it triggers then the effect it has. "you lose all of the money you have" is just not fun. especially if its the last round or the last spin and you cant do anything about it

edit: announcing dlc right after pushing an update that no one liked, barely 2 months after the game came out, is CRAZY

I liked this game a lot, but I cannot in good faith recommend anyone else support the game at this time. The dev is being really rude and hateful to their community members who politely mentioned they disliked an update. This is absolutely unacceptable behavior from a dev team even if it consists of two people. The fact they cut endless mode out is ridiculous too, I'm probably gonna try to get a refund as this is no longer the game I bought.

I was enjoying it, and close to 100%. The latest update changed unlocks to require doubled deadlines (instead of continuing to allow for three wins with the [b][i]option[/i][/b] of one win with doubled deadlines). Most of my runs now end at the first deadline.
It was fun for a hundred or so hours at least.

1.2 botched like 70% of the fun with this game, the whole thrill of a roguelike is the rush of being rewarded with endless potential after utilizing unlocks well and the amount of nerfs (plenty of which were just not needed) just kind of killed that thrive to push the game to its limits.

The significant removal of endless runs is a dissapointing decision made for an overall very fun game,  many of the changes make the game feel less unique and intresting making it stand out less as a unique thing  in the quickly growing economy of gambling based roguelites, the things that made it stand out arent bad by nature of being diffrent.

Until the 1.2 update, game was a bit unbalanced, but fun. The memory card mechanic could have used some tweaks to not lose rare cards when the game just does not want you to even pass the first deadline, but game was fun.

Thanks to a lot of nerfs, not tweaking the cards in a fun/player side way, and introducing crashes to a lot of players, I feel this is not the game I bought. It is a harder, more unfair and less fun version of it.

Do not recommend until a patch goes back on some dumb decisions and corrects some design issues of the base game.
couldnt get passed the first few deadlines, dieing got old fast, normally got loads of time for games like these. but just got frustrating and boring. must of just got all the bad seeds.

As of today's patch, the devs ruined the game and its less fun than it used to be.

Sad L.

Game is fun and all, but you are literally just restart fishing for good items and most runs end in the third step or so due to just RNG and nothing at all you can do about it. Feels very overtuned. The two runs Ive gotten were I DID get far were very enjoyable though. For the most part youre just pulling your hair out over "increase chance to appear" not doing jack shit.
60% chance for clovers? the last 6 spins with no clovers at all but lots of bells and cherries say otherwise.

New update ruined the game. Hard mode should be renamed 'we hate the players mode'. It made the holo memory card grind significantly less fun, nerfed so many items, and buffed only a handful. You'd think this was a battle royale shooter or something with the way the devs are trying to 'balance' and stomp out fun in the game. They are also trying to kill endless runs, which is whatever to me, but sucks in a genre where that is a huge component of these sorts of games.

Good game until 1.2 released which just nerfed a lot of charms for basically no reason and then tries to tease a dlc (at the time of writing this isnt stated to be free or not) for the game. I get that the publisher of this game didnt want to stop the announcement but this is just a really bad decision and having a paid dlc this early is stupid. I wouldnt bother getting the game right now unless they change everything for the better and the dlc is free

This is a mixed review 
TLDR: Game had merit on release, has gotten slightly less fun over updates. Don't recommend if you want endless runs, or very large numbers.

The game was fairly fun around the time it released, but after the 1.2 update it no longer has the same pull it had previously. Cloverpit is relatively easy besides luck. If you know what charms to take and what to do you're pretty much guaranteed a win. 

Now to the problem with the new update, since Cloverpit is simple enough to win if you get lucky, most of the appeal of the game came down to going endless, and getting as big a number as possible. With 1.2 released the devs nerfed most charms adding little to the game, of course this is just balancing, but wait, this is a singleplayer game with no online competition. Nerfs should rarely be included in singleplayer, unless they are literally game breaking e.g. crashing the game from being too powerful, not game breaking in the way that the devs describe, which is just their original idea of the game. 

Devs forcing a playstyle onto players rarely goes well, and comes across as controlling. If your game is "broken" from players doing something you didn't expect, you should embrace it. For example, Peak. Peak had a bug where you could essentially teleport to the end of the game, they patched this since it wasn't intended, but players didn't approve, so they reverted it with a slight change and made it a feature. There is no ranked mode or any competition in Peak, so they didn't mind, so it doesn't make sense when devs do. 

To give the devs some merit, certain endless runs could break the game from overloading it, but I don't see how that is the endless build's fault. If the 64 bit integer overflows and flips back to 0 from getting too many tickets, then instead of nerfing charms that give you tickets, cap the ticket amount so it doesn't flip back over. Which in 1.2 they sort of did, they added the cap to patterns, but not tickets. Instead of adding code fixes, they just nerfed most of the game so you couldn't get there in the first place.

I currently do not recommend this game on one condition, you are looking for a game where a big number gets infinitely bigger, which might be expected from a gambling game, but since the update, the number can no longer get as big. They are apparently making a hotfix for the 1.2 update "that addresses some of the points" (from feedback) but also announced a DLC so I don't believe they will change their ways.

Great concept but gets stale quite fast.
The more you unlock, the more watered down your charm selection gets.
The memory cards are single-use that you have to collect?
There are no carry-over bonuses or upgrades, you can't even block a charm.
And then they tried their best to remove endless runs from the game.
Way to spoil the fun...

Was a great game before the most recent (1.2 Hard mode update). Now the possibility of getting 100% achievements is nigh impossible. Revert the change to allow for the previous win condition (3 normal runs) instead of REQUIRING hard mode (2x blinds), and the hardest card (4x blinds).
if you have fun in a game and the response is having your fun nerfed, then i'm not gonna have fun. if it's not fun, why bother?

Genuinely the concept of the game is super cool. The graphics are really well made and i can see that a lot of love was put into this game. Funny silly gambling game in hell. Getting crazy numbers and endless runs was one of the most fun things. However,,, the recent update:

It was so funny and satisfying but then the game got nerfed and now its not really fun anymore. I don't really get why the developers did it. It's not like it is a multiplayer game that need nerfing down for fairness; its a silly singleplayer roguelike game where you make your own path in uh gambling hell lmao. The game was fairly difficult to begin with which made getting big numbers and endless runs even more rewarding and silly. It just feels like all fun was removed in the latest update. Hopefully they don't make anymore decisions like this in the future. 

Absolutely great game in concept and the devs should be proud of themselves for making it but gahh recent update kinda bad,,,,

It might be a skill issue but sitting down on the first deadline praying I get lucky enough to pass it on the new hard difficulty is not how i imagine 'skill' being tested. It has become a slog trying to make my memory cards rainbow. It honestly feels like such a lazy way to spice up the difficulty.

Game is very fun at first but quickly devolves into an rng hell.  There is very little skill expression at all, and it's mostly just hoping you stumble upon synnergies in the mid game.  If you want to waste your time literally gambling then play this game.

Great game when it came out, love it, beat it, even went after achievements. But after latest update can't even start the game since it crashes every time. I'm on Intel GPU by the way. Also this updates mostly just nerfs good trinkets and gets rid of infinite builds, wich in a single player game feels completely unnecesary. It just ruins the most fun parts of the game in my oppinion. Unfortunetly do not recommend until update is reverted or fixed.

I like 'Balatro', I like 'Slots & Daggers', I got addicted to 'Ball x Pit' and I have addiction issues in general, but this game, somehow, is just lame and ... cringe.

Refunded. Apparently I bought the game at a bad time. Recent update supposedly stealth buffed how often the "666" mechanic comes into play. With a 1.5% chance of a 666 (which clears any earnings for that round) I was managing to get it on every 2nd-3rd pull. Glad I could pull out on this one.

Game is based on randomness with very little player agency. Items to buy are random, there is no real scaling of items, synergy is completely up to chance, and the only way to win is really by pure luck; your actions have very little meaning. This is the biggest issue with Clover Pit, which makes it stand out in a negative way from games like Balatro, where you can actively strategize and have a mix of randomness and skill. That is not here.

Worst of all is that the game has major issues which could be fixed via continuing updates, particularly by giving the player more agency in the outcome of the game. But instead the developers announced a paid DLC. Great example of developers having a neat idea, having no idea how to execute it, and then trying to reap as much money as humanly possible rather than make a decent game.

Buy something else. The devs have the mindset of AAA companies while wearing the cloak of being indie devs.
I was very into this game but the seemingly limited ways to beat the game and the ridiculous RNG I cannot in good faith recommend this.

While the game itself is really good, I can't recommend it seeing what the devs are doing. First they released an "update" that basically adds nothing, nerfs fun items into the ground and makes the deadline scale faster. Questionable, considering this is singleplayer game so all you did was make the game less fun. But what made me write this review, the devs ignored the feedback and announced a DLC. The game has already made them 10M$ and continues to make more. The "DLC" looks like the first major content update that they're locking behind a paywall. If they walk back on some of these terrible decisions I'll gladly change my review to positive, but I don't want to support greedy devs who exploit their fans to make a quick buck.

Zero fun in this game, The free to play demo was good and showed a lot of promise but now the game is pay to play, the difficulty has been set that high that it is just tedious and boring. Save your cash.
Make a bad update > mock players for not liking the changes > announce dlc not 2 months after game released. Randy is that you?

Fantastic game on release. It had the same energy as Balatro while still feeling like a new addition to the rogue-lite market and having a reason to exist. Then came out the videos of streamers and youtubers finding combos of items that would "break" the game and allow for endless runs. That's fine, and I figured that was the whole point of the game, the game presents itself in a manner that it should be broken or that you should find the most broken/OP build.

Then came a rebalancing update that completely nerfed certain items, and completely broke many builds. On top of this, deadline scaling was reworked to make endless runs impossibly more difficult. Why take this away? As many people have voiced, this is a single player game with no currencies or leaderboards or multiplayer. Having OP item combos or infinitely scaling builds did absolutely no harm to the game and was made the game fun for many people. 

Devs originally gave the impression that they were "listening" and were going to make a follow update that put more thought into the balancing changes. Behind the scenes though, they apparently have been mocking players for "skill issues". Isnt the entire point of the game gambling? How does that equate to a skill issue?

The final nail in the coffin for me was that this game released almost 2 months ago. No content updates since then, just a single balancing update that angered a lot of players, and now they have the audacity to announce a paid DLC for this game. No thanks. Y'all can take your paid DLC and shove it. If this is how you're going to treat your community, I'm out.

Really wish game developers would stop catering to the ultra-competative. Just because John Tryhard has a video on youtube showing how they broke the game with different items, doesn't mean they all need to be nerfed. This is just a casual game. There's no leaderboard. So why make things less enjoyable for everyone.

Yes the items could be used to 'break' the game but guess what. That's what roguelite games are all about. Let us have fun.

Shit...

The RNG in this game is set to "Go F*** your self"

Im losing all the memory cards I managed to get and losing within the first 2-3 deadlines all the time now.

Since I got lucky and got the white phone and key the game has just been making me lose.

If I wanted to feel bad about gambling id go to a casino!

um. ok. it's a slot machine game. I didnt hate it but its definitely way over-hyped. why is it so convoluted and why is my POV being forced away from my control here and there. the game gave me head aches just playing an hour. Its like people asking " hurr durr why do you use dark mode maan". It's fine that graphics are artsy blocky pixel kinda way but we gotta read bunch of LONG ASS texts to see what a charm does etc. I dont know if its from the head aches but charm info and their effects could be shown with simpler and better animation and sound feedback perhaps. the only think i can say is when pepper charm shows up, i get more counts. The neko cat, the c4 bomb thingy, that chrystal and battery thingy etc, no idea. Also, there is plenty room on the table for charms but there is an arbitrary limit to how many you can keep? I think if you could hang or insert charms on to the slot machine or something we could clearly see oh there are this many slots for charms etc.

80% of runs are a waste of time and go nowhere without a shot. Maybe if I get lucky and unlock even more things it gets better later on right off the bat? But...screw that? I'd rather just play something else.

The few times you can get lucky and get anything going, it is fun. But they're so few and far between.

weird choices, bad changes, and upcoming dlc releases instead of making the base game better. fun game likely to soon be ruined by awful decisions. maybe they can still recover and fix everything though, so ill wait and see if anything changes for the better.
its fun at first, but it becomes repetitive fast and too easy to win once you know what you're doing

Games actually good depending on your luck run. I've had terrible luck for a majority of this game so my review will stay recommending people against buying it. If you want to make people suffer buy it for them

The game starts off pretty fun but as you progress and unlock charms the chances of starting a winning run diminish fast as the pool of charms gets bloated with things that are pretty useless, making you restart like 9 out of 10 runs.
The latest patch has made it even more difficult to progress by nerfing some of the good charms without improving the filler. The game could also use a lot of QoL improvements, but the latest patch and the dev's response to the backlash isn't inspiring any confidence.

Don't buy the game just play the free demo. It's not worth it, there is nothing in the full release that makes it worth buying.

The reason i bought the game was for the "story" and more items but as it turns out those are the reason why i do not enjoy the full game. After unlocking all the drawers the game just becomes a reset simulator were you hope to get good items. There are so many useless items that it's almost impossible to get the good ones. I have spend days resetting over and over again and i constantly don't make it to the 4rth deadline. I know it has a lot to do with luck but making the game take actual days to get one good run because of the items is bad game design imo.

Visually a neat game, but doesn't really do anything good that I typically look for in this genre. There really is an overwhelming lack of meaningful choice making. Its like if every round of balatro had one hand and zero discards. There's just no interaction in the actual gameplay, and the set-up of your pulls is so abysmally restricting that its not even engaging in that regard.

Sorry, can't recommend this game after the blatantly out of taste update the devs put in.

Absolutely disregarded any feedback from your player base, no QoL improvements, nothing. Just nerfed the game to make it harder and more boring.

I gave this game enough of my time.  Can't take anymore RNG bull sheet.  

Go play Balatro, it's a far better experience.

Spent about 25 hours obsessed with this game, creating fun and profitable builds, and every hour spent in game since has been less fun, Don't know what they're thinking with these updates, or why announcing DLC for a game that still needs some TLC and polish to really be considered a completed game... I hope they're taking this stuff into consideration and make the game fun again

Spin seven times: earn 2 coins. Repeat until you can't pay back 200 coins. At no point did this ever feel like it was going anywhere or getting better with every death. Oh good sometimes cherries can be golden cherries. I'll watch those match with my other non-existent cherries.

Don't buy until the devs revert the patch that killed the viable options in the game. The game needed some balance changes since most of the charms were not even worth trying after reading what they did, but making everything worse wasn't the way.

Was great until the update, double deadline was specific to the golden nob and you just had to play each card 3 times to rainbow it, which was challenging enough imo and the nerfs have ruined the game a bit.

Sadly this feels like changes to appease the tryhards who moan its not challenging enough which is a shame.

This game has a lot of potential and I really enjoyed the early game, but now that I've beaten it a couple times it just isn't fun dying over and over again in deadline 2 or 3 because I can't roll any good items in the shop. Your item pool gets so diluted that it's hard to get the ball rolling on a good build. Part of what makes this game fun is exploiting the items to make insane infinite run builds, but it seems the devs are moving away from that play style in favor of more 'difficulty'. While I understand this game is inherently luck based, it isn't fun to die 5 times in early deadlines in hopes for that 1 good run.
Developers changing the game's rules so the house always wins. 10/10 just like a real casino!

Well unfortunately, i got this after the 1.2 update. Sounds like the game may have been fun prior to this. Wouldn't recommend it now. Earlier builds dont feel satisfying at all and even if you get some insane luck with phone calls, you still just can't seem to to get anything to work for you even if you build for it. Several hours in and there's no meta building that seems to give any kind of edge so you're just kinda stuck slowly slogging through. It needs work

Man I really like this game, but so much about it just makes me want to say don't pick it up until the game gets some serious updates.

The game is fun on its core, but the biggest issues are: no way to turn off the blasting lights, a lack of quality of life. And with this recent update it just made me feel like. Wow. I guess what I thought this game was suppose to be wasn't at all. Devs don't want endless runs, even though they allow it? Like- it's a singleplayer game??? Who cares if you try to go naninf, that's the fun of endless mode. And it's not even really going to help with unlocks regardless.

On top of that the flashing lights is really irritating and gives me a migraine and I don't typically deal with photo-sensitivity, but I cannot in good faith imagine someone with that would even be able to do one go at the spins.

And just like- how is it that AFTER you do the "true ending" the game is still so obtuse with pieces in the drawer or like the skull which for some god damn reason isn't guaranteed you have to roll sometimes upwards of 50 times just to see it on like deadline 3. It boggles my mind how the devs didn't consider how someone might want to actually 10% the game. Especially if you fuck up and have a bad run and need to restart. Welp, time to restart 3 or 4 times to fill the drawer again when it could just, auto be filled after you have beaten the full game. Like. and memory cards do not need to be opened one at a time after you get all of them unlocked. Like. When you play this game so much and need to open like 4-5-6 even it takes forever.

Genuinely wait for this game to update. Or like, get better I don't know. I'm just upset about this latest patch with no real quality of life things.

Number 1 reason for hate is the fact that there is no way to disable animations, you can speed them up up to 4x but that is so slow. And speeding it up even more won't make it better, just add stupid option to disable animations completely.

Second, Memory cards are consumables. Like man you make game more RNG than it needs to be, making it even more RNG to get the Cards in the first place, and you make them consumable. Big red flag.

I wanted to refund it but I was too late.

2/10

The balance was questionable before 1.2 and you had to reset a lot to get a decent run going and after 1.2, it seems like it's not worth the trouble of slogging through the RNG.

But hey, the devs sold their million copies, why should they care about the players that got them there.
Gets boring very fast and releasing a dlc when the base game is still not good is just pure greed

The base game is really good, great amount of fun but, seeing as they plan a DLC, when there could be so many improvements done to the base game... it really takes my mind to a cash grab, quick profit riding the wave of popularity for the game. Util i see otherwise I can't recommend, I only bought it to support the developer, but you can really just grab a free copy off of google if you know what I mean, I would like to withdraw my support for the dev.

This game has one of the most fucking idiotic random imaginable. Fucking dogshit "666" bullshit appears more often than any other symbol, with a 1% probability. It's a stupid, broken random generator. And I won't change my mind until the developers fix this rigged bullshit.

Awful 1.2 update that nerfed way too much. The devs claim that this is to "prevent endless runs" which is just their way of saying that they're anti-fun. Scammed me out of my money, don't let it happen to you, and DEFINITELY don't buy any of their games, whether or not it's good right now.
The latest nerfs were too hard on the core of the game. Expecially for endless runs.
New update ruined it.. way to much RNG now revert the cards back to 3 wins and il like the game again..
There is too little content, the gameplay is too repetitive, and what players can do is quite limited, with only a handful of powerful items available.

I don't know how but they managed to release one of the lamest, anti-fun updates that also completely failed to improve the swath of minor issues that pile up to make the game a boring slog to go for completion. 

There's a severe lack of variety when that vast majority of items are the same thing but for a different symbol. The game is not remotely honest about the chances of symbols and patterns appearing. Even at 4x speed the spins take so long late into a run that it's extremely tedious. Runs will either die on the 1st or 2nd deadline or be a complete joke with zero friction with little exception, the new hard mode does nothing to change this besides the nerfs to a ton of items in the same update, most of them not even good in the first place.

Most confusingly of all, what exactly is the issue with getting a run that can go forever? What is the beef some roguelite devs have with letting a player try to make the biggest number they can, despite that being the whole appeal in the first place? Yeah it's tedious and boring, but when you can end a run at any time, even AFTER you've failed to meet a deadline, it feels insane to tell those people no, they can't have their fun actually so we're gonna artificially make it impossible now.

i really liked this game at first, but i just cannot get behind the latest update, which effectively ruins any way to get far into endless, making it really repetitive and unfun. the combos that were fun to build towards and offered high risk high reward, or just fun gameplay, were nerfed to the ground. 

The game shines in a lot of aspects, and it has love and care put into it, but sometimes there is a line, especially for a rougelite, as the game is at its best when pushed to its limits. even the description of the game itself says the game is broken, and you are MEANT to break the game, so the first update being one that contradicts that feels kind of silly. hopefully you reconsider these changes, as i really love this game.

I have 124 hours in this game. A good chunk of that time is having it up in the background while playing another game that has long queue times. It was a great filler for in between matches. I was looking forward to the challenge of 100%ing this game before update 1.2. Now it feels impossible. I'm 4 charms away from having them all unlocked and don't care in the slightest anymore due to now just playing "Restart the game until you get god tier items AND incredible luck." If you were on the fence, I would either move on from this game or check back in a month or two to see if this worst decision update gets reverted/fixed.

The game had everything to become a nice alternative to Balatro, but the devs decided to go against players, pushing an update that no one asked for, everyone disliked, and now there's no trust what the devs will do next. And despite massive criticism, rather than defend their choice or apologise for a goof, they decide to make a meme on instagram. Until the devs decide to listen to the players feedback i suggest staying away.

While I LOVE roguelites, this one just has too much rng. My last session lasted almost 3 hours in which I didn't have a single good run because the game refused to give me any patterns and I kept losing at the first or second deadline. There is just not enough control over the runs. 

Memory cards could be fun, but again, totally dependent on rng and single use on top of that.
 
I feel like the progression isn't rewarding at all. I can deal with rngsus hating me if a good run would at least reward you with progression, but 1 good run in many hours of gameplay just isn't fun. Any progression you do get, unlocking new items, objectively gives you even less chance of completing a good run because having more options means you need even more luck to get items that synergise to score high enough to meet even the first few deadlines.

It was fun (read: new) for a little bit, but I doubt I'll ever fire up the game again.
